Package org.jtrim2.stream

Class FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T>

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.stream.FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the elements to be processed
public final class FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T> extends Object
Defines a convenient fluent style builder for consumers processing a group of sequences of elements. Instances of this class can be created through the toFluent() method of SeqGroupConsumer.

Mutator like methods always return a new instance and do not change the original FluentSeqGroupConsumer instance.

Thread safety

Instances of this class are immutable, and are therefor safe to be used by multiple threads concurrently. This property does not extend to the wrapped SeqGroupConsumer.

Synchronization transparency

Methods of this class are synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
See Also:
  • SeqConsumer.toFluent()
  • FluentSeqConsumer

  • Method Details

    • apply

      public <T1> FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T1> apply(Function<? super SeqGroupConsumer<T>,? extends SeqGroupConsumer<T1>> configurer)
      Transforms the wrapped SeqGroupConsumer using the given function and returns a fluent style builder for the transformation result. This method exists to allow fluent style continuation using custom transformations. For example: 
      
 builder
     .apply(SeqGroupConsumer::flatteningConsumer)
     // ...

      For an instance of FluentSeqGroupConsumer named builder, this method call is equivalent to configurer.apply(builder.unwrap()).toFluent().

      Type Parameters:
      T1 - the type of the elements processed by the returned consumer
      Parameters:
      configurer - the transformation transforming the wrapped consumer. This argument cannot be null, and the transformation cannot return null.
      Returns:
      the wrapped SeqGroupConsumer transformed using the given function as fluent style builder. This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • SeqGroupConsumer.flatteningConsumer

      Parameters:
      seqGroupConsumer - the consumer applied to the processed elements after this consumer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a consumer first apply this consumer for each processed element, then applying the consumer given in the argument.

    • inBackground

      public FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T> inBackground(String executorName, int consumerThreadCount, int queueSize)
      Returns a consumer resplitting the input sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence on a new separate thread.

      The implementation puts received elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to get further elements. Aside from the potential parallelization, the benefit is that the producer and consumer runs in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

      Parameters:
      executorName - the name given to the executor running the consumer tasks. This name will appear in the name of the executing threads. This argument cannot be null.
      consumerThreadCount - the number of threads processing elements concurrently. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer threads are processing. That is, the threads are effectively act as part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are consumerThreadCount + queueSize. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a consumer resplitting the input sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence on a new separate thread. This method never returns null.

    • inBackground

      public FluentSeqGroupConsumer<T> inBackground(TaskExecutor executor, int consumerThreadCount, int queueSize)
      Returns a consumer resplitting the input sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence in a new separate task of the given executor.

      The implementation puts received elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to get further elements. Aside from the potential parallelization, the benefit is that the producer and consumer runs in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

      Note that it is normally expected that the executor can run consumerThreadCount tasks in parallel (which will run for the whole duration of the whole processing uninterrupted), when submitted from the context where the jobs would be running otherwise. If that is not the case, then the implementation might assume that the jobs submitted to the executor will eventually start for the purpose of queue settings. However, dead-lock will only arise in case not even a single task submitted to the given executor can start running, and in that case dead-lock is a necessity.

      Parameters:
      executor - the executor running the consumer tasks. This argument cannot be null.
      consumerThreadCount - the number of threads processing elements concurrently. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer threads are processing. That is, the threads are effectively act as part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are consumerThreadCount + queueSize. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a consumer resplitting the input sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence in a new separate task of the given executor. This method never returns null
